awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Measurement and Control of Mass and Velocity Rates in Bulk Solids Distribution Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project demonstrates the feasibility of using a new, non-invasive vibroacoustic method that simultaneously measures solids and air flow rates within highly-branched pneumatic conveyance piping. The method determines characteristic vibrations of the piping that is directly related to solids and gas flow, and acoustic emission, within the piping; it is measured via the attachment of accelerometers onto the outside of the piping. Currently, no inexpensive, non-invasive and wireless system is commercially available that can be used to measure and then control solids and gas flow rates in highly-branched piping typical of industrial settings. In all cases, this situation leads to inefficiencies in materials use and distribution, wasted energy, non-optimized process operation and higher operating costs. The research objectives focus on determining vibroacoustic intensities and associated frequencies between 50-10,000 Hz that will define method sensitivity and repeatability, its potential as a self-standardizing and stand-alone approach, and the technical requirements for creating a commercial process control instrument. Because the vibroacoustic measurements will be accomplished at an industrial site where significant equipment and process noise is typical, the anticipated technical results will create a solid foundation and enhance method credibility for subsequent demonstration.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is in wireless process control instrumentation (PCI) that enhances process efficiencies, and in the scientific understanding of non-invasive measurements of solids and gas flows within highly-branched pneumatic conveyance systems. By controlling solids conveyance in these systems, materials usage efficiencies are increased, and product qualities and process performances are raised. As an example, successfully implementing a vibroacoustic PCI at the industrial site at which the vibroacoustic data are to be acquired could decrease its materials usage by up to 40% with a concomitant cost savings of $640,000/yr. Within US industries mandated to install emission equipment, the cost reductions offered by the vibroacoustic method are $384 million per year, and commercial sales of the PCI could reach $155 million. The cost savings and business created would beneficially impact society through decreased energy consumption for manufacturing, transporting and using solid reagents; decreased electrical generation costs; improved environmental performance; decreased emissions of greenhouse gases; and, decreased consumer costs. Furthermore, increased efficiencies in the control of bulk solids delivery using pneumatic conveyance is needed for commodities and high-value products produced by industry that are either consumed or used by, and impact, every person in the US.

por.por_cntn:
During the NSF SBIR Phase I research, Tribo Flow Separations (TFS) demonstrated the feasibility of its acoustic process control instrument (PCI) concept for measuring gas and solids flow rates in highly-branched, pneumatic conveyance systems.  The research proved that an acoustic PCI was a viable and inexpensive approach to measure the distribution of gas and solids within complex conveyance systems and then to control this distribution; besides uncovering the science behind an innovative instrument, the research outcomes offer a solid pathway for inexpensively optimizing efficiencies for distributing products and reagents within industrial conveyance systems.

The research proved that characteristic acoustic emission resulting form gas and solids flows within piping can be readily extracted using contact sensors attached onto piping with diameters between 2-15 centimeters; after applying specialty algorithms, the heretofore unknown vibroacoustic signals were shown to quantitatively determine both air and solids flow rates, and these determinations were independent of other instrumental measurements. The groundbreaking outcomes provide the impetus for commercializing a new acoustic PCI for gas and solids conveyance systems with sensor costs less than one-fifth of those used in commercially available process flow and control instrumentation.

Data acquisition and analyses were accomplished at a full-scale industrial site and within a laboratory setting. The research, and ensuing discussions with both business and University of Kentucky research partners, established the foundation of a fully automated and stand-alone PCI which is to be integrated into commercial installations already utilizing or about to install pneumatic conveyance equipment. Useful and economical for monitoring over 50 conveyance pipes simultaneously, the PCI employs inexpensive contact vibroacoustic detectors, does not require intrusive access into the inside of piping or the introduction of new piping configurations, and would interface with operatins hardware/software via hard-wire or wireless communications.

The SBIR Phase I research focused on demonstrating the PCI concept within the energy production sector where activated carbon and dry sorbent injection (ACI/DSI) systems are under deployment. Use of ACI/DSI is required because new emission control rules promulgated by the US government; an effective acoustic PCI with long-term stability would decrease ACI/DSI usage by up to 40% and provide a savings of over $480 million-per-year for the US economy. Success in this and other targeted markets would:  improve environmental performance of electricity generation, cement manufacturing, petrochemical refining and waste-to-energy product; enhance efficiencies during electricity production and materials manufacturing; decrease greenhouse gas emissions; lower electrical costs for rate payers; and reduce emission that can affect human health.

TFS cooperatively demonstrated acoustic PCI concepts with its team members, and is poised to demonstrate its usefulness within a full-scale commercial installation during follow-on research and development which is also to include assessments within a broad base of potential end users. During performance of the SBIR, three PhD students and one Post-Doctorate were trained in advanced research techniques for instrumentation development; professional research presentations and publications were scheduled in which the technical aspects and benefits of the acoustic PCI are to be discussed; and two US patents were written which are scheduled to be filed during the first months of 2015.
